description: From Middle English halten, from Old English healtian (“to be lame, walk with a limp”), from Proto-Germanic *haltōną. English usage in the sense of 'make a halt' is from the noun. Cognate with North Frisian halte, Swedish halta.

verbs.description: halt (third-person singular simple present halts, present participle halting, simple past and past participle halted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To limp; move with a limping gait.
(intransitive) To stand in doubt whether to proceed, or what to do; hesitate; be uncertain; linger; delay; mammer.
(intransitive) To be lame, faulty, or defective, as in connection with ideas, or in measure, or in versification.

description: From Middle French halt, from early modern German halt (“stop!”), imperative of halten (“to hold, to stop”). More at hold.

entries.meaning: A cessation, either temporary or permanent.
examples: The contract negotiations put a halt to operations.

entries.meaning: (rail transport) A minor railway station (usually unstaffed) in the United Kingdom.
examples: The halt itself never achieved much importance, even with workers coming to and from the adjacent works.

verbs.description: halt (third-person singular simple present halts, present participle halting, simple past and past participle halted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To stop either temporarily or permanently.

examples: The contract negotiations halted operations for at least a week.

description: From Middle English halt, from Old English healt, from Proto-Germanic *haltaz (“halt, lame”), from Proto-Indo-European *kol-d-, from Proto-Indo-European *kel- (“to beat, strike, cut, slash”). Cognate with Danish halt, Swedish halt.

adjectives.description: halt (comparative more halt, superlative most halt)
